headline: Greek Tzatziki
description: The best tzatziki sauce recipes allow chilling time for the fresh flavors of dill, lemon, cucumber, and garlic to blend into the yogurt.
name: Greek Tzatziki
recipeIngredient: 1 tablespoon freshly ground black pepper, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Combine yogurt, grated cucumber, lemon juice, olive oil, and garlic together in a large bowl. Add dill, salt, pepper, and lemon zest; mix until smooth.
Pour into a serving dish, cover tightly, and refrigerate 8 hours before serving.

review.reviewBody: Cool and creamy, but I missed a subtle taste of onion so I put a half teaspoon of onion powder in and woke that baby up just a tudge. Made it much more wowzer! Used it to make 3 dishes, Instead of chicken livers used chicken breasts in the stroganoff, chicken in gyro with homemade tzatziki sauce, and baked chicken breasts with yogurt sauce. The only thing extra is my 5lbs.

Feel free to experiment (or substitute entirely) with 1 to 3 tablespoons of freshly chopped cilantro (aka coriander) and/or parsley in place of or in addition to the recipe's call for dill. You may also wish to try adding some heat by adding one (and only 1) Serrano pepper (they look like really skinny fingers and come in colors of green and red) to your Tzatzeki recipe (chopped finely). But beware of adding too much heat: those rounded and colorful chilis (called Habanero peppers) are way too hot and will ruin your Tzatzek yogurt dip). The only other veggie i would add would be finely chopped onion.
My first attempt at tzatziki and it was very good! I shredded the cucumber very fine, I think that was key. Also made about 1/10th of this recipe! - Aug 2022
Delicious. We went with the full fat yogurt. We always do. Don't skimp or settle on taste is our motto. And as a nod to the dish, we went with greek yogurt. turkish yogurt is good as well.
Too much salt!
Wish I would have read reviews first. Choked on the salt and pepper. Use like half. So surprized. First bad recipe from Allrecpies.

This is excellent. I used 24 oz of Greek yogurt because that's what my grocery store sells, not 32 oz. And it is safe to assume the TBSP of salt and pepper are typos so I used a tsp of each. Other than that I made exactly as written. I let it sit in frig for 24 hours and the flavor just got better. My family loved it.
Very tasty sauce. I did add more garlic.
Makes a lot.
This was sooooo tasty and easy to make! I made it the day before our family dinner and just kept it in the fridge until I needed it.

This is the best recipe for tzatziki I’ve tried. I halved the recipe and added 2 green onions, white part only, and omitted the lemon zest. I also made a garlic paste with the minced garlic and I think that really helped combine all the flavors together. So yummy with grilled chicken and veggies kabobs!
Too much lemon for my taste. Next time will eliminate the lemon zest. Also, 1 tablespoon of salt is way too much?
I did remove the fluid from the yogurt and cucumber. I cut the salt and pepper in half. Didn’t have dill so went without it. It was so good!! Thanks for the tips. I will definitely make this again.

Three stars as written. To make it 5 stars, use half the amount of yogurt and use full fat Greek or Mediterranean yogurt. Use an entire English cucumber, 4 fresh cloves of garlic grated on a microplane. Grate the cucumber into a fine mesh strainer, mix it with a tablespoon of kosher salt and let drain in the fridge overnight. Add the grated garlic to the lemon juice and let that sit overnight as well to mellow the heat from the garlic. 

Next day, squeeze any remaining liquid from the cucumber and mix with the yogurt along with the garlic-lemon juice mixture. Add chopped fresh dill to your taste or use mint instead, entirely a personal choice. Finally mix in a tablespoon of good quality EVOO. Put it back in the fridge for at least an hour or two to give the flavours a chance to blend. Taste and adjust sale if necessary and add some freshly ground black pepper or mix in some white pepper if you don't want any black flecks in the mix. 

Makes a fantastic side dip for Greek chicken brochettes and Greek roasted potatoes.

After spending a long vacation in Greece we came home and craved this sauce something fierce. After playing around with numerous recipes and yogurts (very important to get the right one) this recipe won out. So our favorite yogurt to use is Cabot Greek Yogurt. Beats anything else by a mile! Also a note on the cucumber. After using the shredder sprinkle with salt to let it sweat for a few minutes and then just squeeze out the juice by picking up and squeezing a handful at a time. This way your sauce doesn't get runny. Enjoy!

It was a little bland so I increased the garlic, lemon juice, and olive oil, and fresh dill. It was way too salty so I’d def reduce the salt considerably next time. It was ok but there was something missing.
Great recipe! I used Greek yogurt so I wouldn't have to strain it and it worked out great. I would just cut down the salt next time. A full tablespoon is overpowering.
LeeleeCooks I do applaud you!This tastes very authentic! There is a wonderful community of Greeks near where I live. They own quite a few businesses and sell a similar Ztatziki to yours.
Very good! I only used 1 tbs of olive oil and regular plain greek yogurt, but very tasty on chicken pita for supper and a greek omelet for breakfast.

I love this. I didn’t have fresh dill but had some I dehydrated last year...it work just fine. The salt needs cut back, a lot. I use 1/2 - 1 teaspoon (same for the pepper) and it is so much better. Overall a great recipe.
Awesome
Not bad but needs to be thicker. Maybe double the dewatered cucumber.

Hmm, kinda hard to get past the sweetness...didn’t realize I bought a Vanilla flavoured Greek yogurt until I tasted the creation. Oops! Wipl never make that mistake again. Perhaps my kids will really like it now.
I added 1/2 cup of sour cream and left out the lemon zest, but added a third tablespoon of lemon juice.
Good overall, but agree with others to cut the salt in half at least.
Such a lovely recipe ! I added 3x the garlic, extra lemon juice & a teaspoon more of Himalayan pink salts
As some suggested, I used low fat plain greek yogurt. I also salted the grated cucumber and then soaked up the excess liquid with paper towels. Used MUCH less salt. It was great!
Depends what yogurt i use!
Needs more garlic. But amazing!

Very good! I did think it was too peppery, but otherwise, it's a great recipe. I didn't use the highest-quality pepper, so that may have been the issue. I used about 1.5 tablespoons of lemon zest rather than the full 2 tbsp, but otherwise, followed the recipe as is.

I paired this with a Greek lemon chicken and potato bake from the site.
Yum, I could eat this all by itself!
Just did. Darn thing works.

Very good but in my opinion way too much lemon and not enough garlic. I say do half the lemon twice the garlic and you’re good to go! I used plain Greek yogurt nice consistency to it. Will definitely make again once I dilute mine with ingredients to get the insane lemon taste out

Great recipe! I reduced the amount of S&P, added a dash of hot sauce to round out the flavor (that is probably not Greek). Letting the flavors marry right now, can’t wait to serve it on burgers tonight!
This turned out so good. I didn’t use as much salt as recipe called for though. My 17 year old son is in love with it.
Excellent!
Coul
Excellent. I did use 5% Greek yogurt, however. The fat free kind just doesn't do it for me.

With a few adjustments this was well liked. Salt cucumber in a strainer & let sit for awhile to remove water. We used lime juice. 1/2 recipe is enough for 4 servings. Also peel cucumber & remove seeds, then grate it.

Made as written, but using 1/2 tbsb salt & pepper, as suggested. 

Close as I’ll ever come to the Greek restaurant in my hometown.
Excellent sauce for gyros.
Fantastic
Great recipe
Best tzatziki I have had, hubby agrees. I used Greek yogurt 11% so didn't drain. Perfect consistency. Thank you for the fabulous recipe!
I added 2 cloves of garlic, and a whole cucumber because I like it chunky, and a little more olive oil. Delicious!

Deducting a star because I made changes to it. Original recipe has WAY too much salt, I would reduce it to maybe 1 teaspoon. I also reduced the dill a bit for personal preference. Overall pretty good.
I made this with falafel and pita and it turned out perfectly! This will be the only tzatziki recipe I make from now on (and always with Greek yogurt)!
Whoa. WAYYYYYY too salty. I should've trusted my gut and used half the salt and slowly added more... Definitely cut back the salt, people.
I used Greek yogurt so no draining required. I just increased the garlic to 2 cloves, used a whole cucumber (drained it couple hours) and eliminated the zest. Only 1/4 tsp salt and pepper. Perfect!

Awesome recipe. For years we have paid a small fortune to purchase some from our favorite restaurant. Now I will just make it at home. I used plain 2% Greek yogurt, which skips the step of straining and removing excess liquid from plain yogurt. After grating the cucumber on the larger edge of the grater, I squeezed paper towels on top of the cucumber to remove excess liquid and the end result was nice thick tzatziki. I also used less salt. Less is more and you can always add more, but you can’t take some out once you’ve used too much. I did not have too much time to let it sit for 8 hours, but ate it within a couple of hours of making it. It was ALMOST as good as it was the next day, so if you don’t have time to let it sit, don’t worry too much. Thank you for an awesome recipe and thanks to other reviewers for suggestions on making this
Just like the tzatziki I had in Greece, very good!
Delicious! Mom immediately asked me to make more!
Everyone loved this recipe, I served it with warm naan bread the first day and nachos the second. I did not have a lemon so used a lime instead which worked out well.
It was very nice, everyone loved it. I would use Greek yogurt next time so it would be thicker.
Amazing!

This was a nice dip for some Greek chicken and vegetables we served to guests. I did follow the advice of other reviewers and I made a few alterations. I used 1 tsp. of pink salt and 1 tsp. of course black pepper , left out the fresh dill and added just a pinch of dry dill, left out the olive oil and I strained my yogurt to thicken it. I think in the future I will reduce the lemon juice just a little bit. It seemed to overwhelm the other flavors. The dip does get better with age. I think this is something that is easily adjustable to individual preference. I would have this again but I wouldn't make as much. We had a ton leftover!
Very delicious. I don't have lemon so I used line instead and dry dill. Ummmm... is definitely share this recipe and will be making again and again. Thanks for sharing
Good tzatziki sauce! I used Greek yogurt and a regular cucumber because that is what I had. I also reduced the salt as recommended. Let it come together for a while before serving. Very good!
I didn't have to let mine marinate and it was still very tasty. I can only imagine letting it sit in the fridge would have made it better.
Delicious!
This was good tzatziki! Not quite what I'm used to, but wonderful nonetheless. Was served with Greek chicken, rice, cucumbers, pita bread and feta cheese.
I love this recipe! I used the Greek yogurt and it comes out perfect Everytime. I live it on a low carb soft tortilla with Monty Jack cheese, sliced deli turkey, oinion and tomato! Best lunch ever!

This is easily the best tzatziki I've made. And I've tried several recipes from this site and others. Excellent recipe. The only change I would make is to leave out either the lemon juice or the lemon zest, because both, I felt, were a little too strong. That being said, this recipe replicates my favorite Greek restaurant's tzatziki. And I was beginning to think I'd never find a recipe so delicious! Love this!! Will make it again and again!

I believe that this the best Tzatziki sauce I have ever had, bar none. I used full fat Greek yogurt so there was no need for straining. I only used 16 ounces of yogurt but left everything else the same, except the salt and pepper. I think that 1 Tablespoon of salt and pepper has to be a mistake. I used 1 teaspoon of each and it was perfect. Do not skip the lemon zest; I believe that is what made this so good.

This sounded so good, and I'm trying to find new things for lunches that are low calorie. I grilled some chicken breasts and made this sauce exactly as is. I cut up the chicken into strips, take 2-3 of those and about 1-2 oz of the sauce to work and it is perfect! It tastes better every day! Thank you for this recipe! I will make it over and over!

All the right ingredients but WAY to much salt and pepper. I wonder if the author meant teaspoon. As is, this recipe is not edible. Waste of ingredients. 

I made this recipe with only 1 teaspoon of each salt and pepper and it was delicious.
No changes necessary. The second time I made it, I didn't have enough greek yogurt. I added 1/2 sour cream and 1/2 yogurt instead. It was still good, requiring a little less lemon.
Perfect recipe and directions. I have saved this and will keep making it!
I think a bit less lemon juice next time. Used the Greek yogurt everyone recommended, really enjoyed it.
Perfect!

Loved this tzatziki recipe! I didn't have a real lemon on hand, so used lemon juice and omitted the zest. Next time I'll use a real lemon but it was still great without it. Also drained the yogurt, which really made it thick and creamy. This is a keeper!

This was awesome! I paired it with my Greek chicken kabobs and some warm pita. GONE! I used plain Greek yogurt and grated the peeled cucumber. I pressed between paper towels to absorb the excess moisture. The only alteration I made was I didn't have a fresh lemon so I used Realemon instead. Came out beautifully thick - not soupy. Will definitely make this again, and again.
I did not make any major changes, I just used lime juice instead of lemon juice and then I used lemon zest. Otherwise, same, same.

Although i do not eat tzatziki, i made it for my spouse. Instead of low fat i used 3% Greek yogurt. I also seeded the cucumber, diced it very fine, and put it in a colander with the salt. After 1 hour i rinsed it under cold water and dried it on paper towels. She had it with Greek ground meat kabobs and pitas. She said it was the best she has ever tasted, bar none. Mike

Very tasty. Just another tip to avoid a watery Tzatziki. Squeeze out the grated cucumber between your fingers to get rid of the water. The same advice for watery yoghurt. I also added more lemon juice to get it tasting very zingy and a bit more garlic.
Yum, very good recipe and easy
Delicious! I just cut in half the portions on the recipe to make it smaller. I used a 17 ounce Greek yogurt container instead.

My go-to tzatziki recipe. Delicious and the kids love it just as a dip. Made 1/2 recipe with 1 smallish cucumber. Grated it, took out seeds and drained in a strainer. Then added the rest of the ingredients. Used homegrown fresh dill. Needs less salt, maybe 1 tsp. Nice and thick.

I made the following changes that positively impacted our tzatziki:
*1 large container (35.3 oz) of plain Greek Fage 2% yogurt, no draining or bleeding off whey required. 
*1 whole cucumber - seeded, peeled, grated & squeezed of juice.
*1 1/2 tsp Kosher salt.
*1/2 tsp black pepper, fresh cracked.
*Added 2+ Tbsp fresh mint, chopped.

drain cucumber 1st - per chef john.
Don't add salt as its already been added when cucs were drained. split dill and mint, used greek yougurt

This is a good recipe all around and easy to follow. I did make a few modifications: instead of juice from a lemon, I used 4 drops of lemon essential oil; instead of 1 tablespoon of salt, I used four twists of Himalayan salt from a grinder; instead of 1 tablespoon of pepper, I put less than 1/4 tsp. I also tossed in 1 tablespoon of mint. After I mixed all of the ingredients, I took a taste test, and the recipe came out fabulous! It tastes like the restaurant made Tzatziki sauce that I absolutely love! Can't wait to taste it after 8 hrs!
Way too much salt.
Very good. Highly recommended putting your salt over your grated cucumber and pressing the liquid out.
Super easy, and fantastically good!

This was too salty for my liking. 
I wish I would have read the previous reviews about the salt. 
The second time I made it, I cut down on the salt and and it was much better.

I have been trying to make a tzatziki I like for such a long time and I finally did it thanks to this recipe! The only things I changed were to eliminate dill (blecch) and roast the garlic before mincing to smooth out the flavor. This sauce is so good I want to lick the plate!
I and my family enjoyed this very much with our dinner on Greek food night.
The only thing that would improve this dip is by straining the fresh grated cucumber and the yogurt. It will make it a but thicker. If you like a thinner dip then this is perfect.
Very good. I think the salt and the lemon need to be cut back but still quite nice. Do use Greek yogurt.
Loved it. Even more once I added some extra garlic. Other comments about using less salt is true this and the pepper should only be about 1 teaspoon NOT tablespoon
It became watery .
Beautiful tzatziki! I made this with one tsp of salt instead of one tbsp and doubled the garlic - so good!

This Tzatiki recipe is great! Next time I will cut the salt and pepper amount in half. It was a little too salty for my taste. I added sour cream to make it less salty and a little creamier, it tastes amazing! I highly recommend this recipe!

I made Tzatziki sauce for first time and decided to use this recipe because it called for dill. I did use greek yogurt and strained it for just a few hours in cheesecloth. I don't really feel this was necessary as I collected very little liquid. I have to agree with cutting back on the lemon and salt. I cut back on the salt by half while making the sauce (as I don't like a lot of salt) but failed to read about cutting back on the lemon. You really need only half of what is called for. I also used only 1 tablespoon of olive oil. I used a regular cucumber, seeded and partially peeled before I grated it. The end result was great. It does however come out thick which is what I intended. For those of you who want a thinner sauce try using half regular yogurt with greek yogurt. To make this recipe I used 4 small (7 oz) containers of Fage 2% greek yogurt.

The people having issues with the saltiness, it is probably your choice of salt, not all salts are created equal. Based upon the amounts listed they should have been specific about the type of salt. Use Kosher salt in this recipe not table salt and you will find it is just right.
Very good! I cut back on the salt, but other than that I followed the recipe. Actually, since there were only three of us, I made a half recipe. Looking forward to having more tomorrow.
Pretty good Tzatziki sauce recipe!
i skipped out on olive oil, added WAY less salt and less black pepper. yummy!

I will definitely make this again. The one thing I added was about 1/4th cup of cilantro and instead of lemon zest I used lemon pepper and omitted the pepper in the recipe. Oh and less salt as recommended by other users. My husband absolutely loved this with pita chips.
